questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with abdominal pain and a pelvic mass. Histological examination of the ovarian tumor reveals the presence of Schiller-Duval bodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Yolk sac tumor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Dysgerminoma are type of ovarian germ cell tumor , but they are characterized by monotonous sheets of large , undifferentiated cells resembling primordial germ cells .
  • • Option
  • • A
  • • Dysgerminoma
  • • ovarian germ cell tumor
  • • monotonous sheets of large
  • • undifferentiated cells
  • • primordial germ cells
  • • Option B . Teratoma are composed of multiple germ cell layers and can contain a variety of tissues such as epithelium, hair , and cartilage .
  • • Option
  • • B
  • • Teratoma
  • • composed of multiple germ cell layers
  • • contain a variety of tissues
  • • epithelium, hair
  • • cartilage
  • • Option D . Granulosa cell tumors are sex cord-stromal tumors , and they are characterized by the presence of Call-Exner bodies . These bodies are small, eosinophilic fluid-filled spaces surrounded by granulosa cells.
  • • Option
  • • D
  • • Granulosa cell tumors
  • • sex cord-stromal tumors
  • • presence of Call-Exner bodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of Schiller-Duval bodies in an ovarian mass biopsy is pathognomonic for yolk sac tumors , also known as endodermal sinus tumors , and is the most likely diagnosis in a young woman presenting with these histological findings.
  • ➤ presence of Schiller-Duval bodies
  • ➤ ovarian mass biopsy
  • ➤ pathognomonic for yolk sac tumors
  • ➤ endodermal sinus tumors
  • ➤ young woman
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1025
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1025

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was investigated for infertility. Semen analysis revealed azoospermia and biopsy was taken which is shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis in the patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sertoli cell only tumor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation;
  • • Option A. Orchitis usually presents with signs of inflammation, not solely with the absence of germ cells as in the biopsy image.
  • • Option A.
  • • Orchitis
  • • Option C . Testicular atrophy involves shrinkage and decreased cellular density in the seminiferous tubules, ofte accompanied by fibrosis, which is not demonstrated in the biopsy provided.
  • • Option C
  • • Testicular atrophy
  • • Option D . Non-seminomatous germ cell tumors typically display malignant cells with various histologic patterns, which are not evident in the biopsy image.
  • • Option D
  • • Non-seminomatous germ cell tumors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sertoli cell only syndrome, also known as germ cell aplasia, is diagnosed when testicular biopsy reveals seminiferous tubules with only Sertoli cells and an absence of germ cells, correlating with clinical findings of azoospermia and infertility in a male patient.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman undergoes a breast biopsy after a suspicious mammogram. Histological examination reveals a tumor with lack of tubule formation, discohesive cells and a low mitotic rate. Immunohistochemistry shows positive estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) staining. What is the most likely histological type of breast cancer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Invasive lobular carcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Invasive ductal carcinoma tends to form glandular structures and does not usually present with the "Indian file" pattern of cell arrangement seen in invasive lobular carcinoma.
  • • Option A.
  • • Invasive ductal carcinoma
  • • glandular structures
  • • Option C. Medullary carcinoma has a higher mitotic rate and a lymphocytic infiltrate , which differs from the low mitotic rate and discohesive cells described in the biopsy report.
  • • Option C.
  • • Medullary carcinoma
  • • higher mitotic rate
  • • lymphocytic infiltrate
  • • Option D . Ductal carcinoma in situ represents an early form of breast cancer that is confined to the ducts and usually forms duct-like structures, unlike the pattern described.
  • • Option D
  • • Ductal carcinoma
  • • in situ
  • • early form of breast cancer
  • • confined to the ducts

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Invasive lobular carcinoma is characterized by the absence of tubule formation , discohesive cells , a low mitotic rate , and positive hormone receptor status .
  • ➤ Invasive lobular carcinoma
  • ➤ absence of tubule formation
  • ➤ discohesive cells
  • ➤ low mitotic rate
  • ➤ positive hormone receptor status

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents for evaluation of a hard, poorly defined mass in her left breast. She reports no pain or discharge, but she has noted a recent change in the shape of the breast. There is no family history of breast cancer. A mammogram reveals microcalcifications in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. A biopsy of the lesion is performed. The type of mammary ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) most likely to result in a palpable abnormality in the breast is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Comedo DCIS

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Apocrine DCIS presents with characteristic apocrine cytologic features under microscopy but is not the most likely to form a palpable mass.
  • • Option A.
  • • Apocrine DCIS
  • • characteristic apocrine cytologic features under microscopy
  • • Option B. Neuroendocrine DCIS is a rare form and typically does not present as a palpable lesion in the breast.
  • • Option B.
  • • Neuroendocrine DCIS
  • • rare form
  • • Option C. Well-differentiated DCIS may show microcalcifications on mammography , but palpable masses are less common than in the comedo subtype.
  • • Option C.
  • • Well-differentiated DCIS
  • • show microcalcifications
  • • mammography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Comedo DCIS is most likely to present as a palpable mass due to the associated necrosis and calcifications . It is often found on mammography and can form a more solid , palpable lesion compared to other subtypes of DCIS.
  • ➤ Comedo DCIS
  • ➤ present as a palpable mass
  • ➤ associated necrosis
  • ➤ calcifications
  • ➤ found on mammography
  • ➤ form a more solid
  • ➤ palpable lesion
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1060
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1060

questions.text: BRCA 1 gene is located on:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chromosome 17

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Tumor-suppressor gene , BRCA-1 (17q21) encodes a zinc finger protein , and the product therefore may function as a transcription factor. The gene appears to be involved in gene repair . BRCA-2 (13q12) is also associated with an increased incidence of breast cancer in men and women .
  • • Tumor-suppressor gene , BRCA-1 (17q21) encodes a zinc finger protein , and the product therefore may function as a transcription factor. The gene appears to be involved in gene repair .
  • • Tumor-suppressor gene
  • • BRCA-1
  • • encodes
  • • zinc finger protein
  • • product
  • • involved in gene repair
  • • BRCA-2 (13q12) is also associated with an increased incidence of breast cancer in men and women .
  • • BRCA-2
  • • associated with an increased incidence of breast cancer
  • • men and women
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • :
  • • BRCA 1 gene is located on Chromosome 17q and BRCA2 gene is located on chromosome 13q.
  • • BRCA 1 gene
  • • Chromosome 17q
  • • BRCA2 gene
  • • chromosome 13q.
  • • Ref : Robbin 10 th / 1045
  • • Ref
  • • : Robbin 10 th / 1045

questions.text: Increased susceptibility to sporadic breast cancer is likely to be associated with a mutation in the following gene?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) p53

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. The BRCA1 gene mutation carries a high risk for developing breast and ovarian cancers . Individuals with this mutation have a lifetime risk of breast cancer that is significantly higher than the general population.
  • • Option B.
  • • BRCA1 gene mutation
  • • high risk for developing breast
  • • ovarian cancers
  • • Option C . While the Rb gene is crucial in controlling cell proliferation and its mutation is primarily associated with retinoblastoma , it is not a leading cause of breast cancer.
  • • Option C
  • • Rb gene
  • • controlling cell proliferation
  • • mutation
  • • associated with retinoblastoma
  • • Option D . H-Ras is part of the Ras gene family ; while mutations in these genes can lead to cancer , they are not typically associated with hereditary breast cancer syndromes.
  • • Option D
  • • H-Ras
  • • part of the Ras gene family
  • • mutations
  • • genes can lead to cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The p53 gene mutation is the most important gene mutation increasing susceptibility to breast cancer .
  • ➤ p53 gene mutation
  • ➤ most important gene mutation increasing susceptibility
  • ➤ breast cancer
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1051
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1051

questions.text: A female patient presented with a firm mass of 2 × 2 cm in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. She gives a family history of ovarian carcinoma. The investigation that needs to be done to assess for mutations is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) BRCA2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The p53 gene , when mutated , can lead to a variety of cancers ; however, in the context of a family history suggesting a hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome, BRCA1 and BRCA2 gene testing is more directly relevant.
  • • Option A.
  • • The p53 gene
  • • mutated
  • • variety of cancers
  • • Option C . Her 2/Neu gene amplification is associated with breast cancer aggressiveness and treatment decisions but is not a part of routine genetic screening for hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome.
  • • Option C
  • • Her 2/Neu gene
  • • associated with breast cancer aggressiveness
  • • treatment decisions
  • • Option D. C-myc is an oncogene implicated in the pathogenesis of various cancers , including breast cancer , but it does not have a direct role in hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndromes.
  • • Option D.
  • • C-myc
  • • oncogene implicated
  • • pathogenesis of various cancers
  • • breast cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ BRCA2 genetic testing is indicated in a patient with a breast mass and a family history of ovarian carcinoma , as mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes are strongly associated with hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndromes .
  • ➤ BRCA2 genetic testing
  • ➤ breast mass
  • ➤ family history of ovarian carcinoma
  • ➤ mutations
  • ➤ BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes
  • ➤ hereditary breast
  • ➤ ovarian cancer syndromes
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1058
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1058

questions.text: All invasive breast carcinomas are graded histologically with the following scoring system:
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Nottingham

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a suspicious breast mass. A core biopsy is performed, and immunohistochemistry (IHC) reveals a HER2/neu score of 2. Given the equivocal HER2 status, which technique is most appropriate for further evaluation to determine the HER2/neu gene amplification status?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR ) is a technique used to amplify DNA but is not typically employed to assess gene amplification status. It is more suitable for studying the presence or absence of specific DNA sequences.
  • • Option A. Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR
  • • technique
  • • amplify DNA
  • • Option C. Southern blotting is a technique used to detect specific DNA sequences in a DNA sample .
  • • Option C. Southern blotting
  • • detect specific DNA sequences
  • • DNA sample
  • • Option D. Western blotting is a technique used to detect specific proteins in a sample . It is not applicable to assess gene amplification and is more suited for protein analysis.
  • • Option D. Western blotting
  • • detect specific proteins in a sample

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of equivocal HER2/neu IHC results which is IHC score of 2 , further recommended technique is Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization (FISH) for evaluation of HER2/neu gene amplification status in breast cancer .
  • ➤ equivocal HER2/neu IHC
  • ➤ IHC score of 2
  • ➤ Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization
  • ➤ HER2/neu gene amplification status
  • ➤ breast cancer

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a palpable lump in her left breast. A biopsy is performed, and the histopathological examination reveals invasive ductal carcinoma. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) shows a HER2/neu score of 3+. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's breast cancer?

options.label: B
options.text: Administer chemotherapy with doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Prescribe trastuzumab

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. While hormonal therapy is an essential part of the treatment for hormone receptor-positive breast cancer , the HER2/neu status of the tumor guides the use of targeted therapies such as trastuzumab.
  • • Option A.
  • • hormonal therapy
  • • treatment for hormone receptor-positive breast cancer
  • • Option B. Chemotherapy may be a component of treatment for breast cancer, but for HER2/neu-positive tumors, trastuzumab is a key targeted therapy that has been shown to significantly improve outcomes.
  • • Option B.
  • • Chemotherapy
  • • component of treatment for breast cancer,
  • • Option D. Radiotherapy could be part of the comprehensive treatment for breast cancer , particularly for local control, but is not directly related to the HER2/neu overexpression finding.
  • • Option D.
  • • Radiotherapy
  • • comprehensive treatment for breast cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient with a HER2/neu score of 3+ indicating HER2 protein overexpression , trastuzumab is the most appropriate next step for targeted therapy in the management of HER2-positive breast cancer.
  • ➤ HER2/neu score of 3+ indicating HER2 protein overexpression
  • ➤ trastuzumab

questions.text: A 50-year-old postmenopausal woman is diagnosed with estrogen receptor-positive (ER+) and progesterone receptor-positive (PR+) invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast. What is the most appropriate adjuvant endocrine therapy for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) like tamoxifen

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) An aromatase inhibitor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Tamoxifen, a SERM , can be used in postmenopausal women but is often reserved for those who cannot tolerate aromatase inhibitors or for premenopausal women.
  • • Option B. Tamoxifen, a SERM
  • • used in postmenopausal women
  • • cannot tolerate aromatase inhibitors
  • • Option C. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists are used in premenopausal women to suppress ovarian estrogen production , which is not applicable in postmenopausal women.
  • • Option C. Gonadotropin-releasing
  • • hormone agonists
  • • premenopausal women
  • • suppress ovarian estrogen production
  • • Option D. Progestin therapy is not typically used in the treatment of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer .
  • • Option D. Progestin therapy
  • • hormone receptor-positive breast cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a postmenopausal woman with ER+ and PR+ breast cancer , the most appropriate adjuvant endocrine therapy is an aromatase inhibitor , which has been shown to be more effective than tamoxifen in this patient population.
  • ➤ postmenopausal woman
  • ➤ ER+ and PR+ breast cancer
  • ➤ endocrine therapy
  • ➤ aromatase inhibitor
  • ➤ effective than tamoxifen

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a painless breast lump that has been gradually increasing in size over the past few months. On examination, a well-defined, mobile, rubbery mass is palpable in the upper outer quadrant of her left breast. Mammography reveals a well-circumscribed, round mass without microcalcifications. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fibroadenoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Invasive Ductal Carcinoma (IDC): it is the most common type of breast cancer. It often presents as an irregularly shaped mass with spiculated margins on imaging. Microcalcifications are a common finding in IDC. Unlike fibroadenomas, IDC tends to infiltrate surrounding tissues invasively.
  • • Option A. Invasive Ductal Carcinoma (IDC):
  • • Option C. Ductal Carcinoma in Situ (DCIS): it is a non-invasive condition where abnormal cells are found in the lining of a breast duct but have not invaded surrounding tissues. It is usually detected through mammography and does not typically present as a palpable mass.
  • • Option C. Ductal Carcinoma in Situ (DCIS):
  • • non-invasive condition
  • • abnormal cells are found in the lining
  • • breast duct
  • • Option D. Phylloides Tumor are rare fibroepithelial tumors that may mimic fibroadenomas clinically . They are typically larger than fibroadenomas and may have a leaf-like appearance on imaging . Phylloides tumors have a potential for rapid growth and a higher risk of recurrence compared to fibroadenomas.
  • • Option D. Phylloides Tumor
  • • rare fibroepithelial tumors
  • • mimic fibroadenomas clinically
  • • larger
  • • fibroadenomas
  • • leaf-like appearance on imaging

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fibroadenoma is the most likely diagnosis for a young woman presenting with a well-defined, mobile, rubbery breast mass and a mammogram showing a well-circumscribed, non-calcified round lesion.
  • ➤ Fibroadenoma
  • ➤ young woman
  • ➤ well-defined, mobile, rubbery breast mass
  • ➤ mammogram
  • ➤ well-circumscribed, non-calcified round lesion.

questions.text: Which is not a correct match for the following ovarian tumors and their histological findings?

options.label: C
options.text: Yolk sac tumor: Schiller Duval body

options.label: D
options.text: Granulosa cell tumor: Call Exner body

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dysgerminoma: Nonlymphocytic infiltration

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Correct. Teratomas are mixed germ cell tumors that can contain various types of tissue , such as hair, skin, and teeth, reflecting their origin from multiple germ layers.
  • • Option A. Correct.
  • • Teratomas
  • • mixed germ cell tumors
  • • various types of tissue
  • • hair, skin,
  • • teeth,
  • • Option C. Correct. Yolk sac tumors are characterized by the presence of Schiller-Duval bodies , a distinctive histological feature.
  • • Option C. Correct.
  • • Yolk sac tumors
  • • presence of Schiller-Duval bodies
  • • Option D. Correct . Granulosa cell tumors are often characterized by the presence of Call-Exner bodies.
  • • Option D. Correct
  • • Granulosa cell tumors
  • • presence of Call-Exner bodies.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dysgerminomas typically exhibit lymphocytic infiltration , not nonlymphocytic infiltration , distinguishing them from the other tumor types listed. This is crucial for pathology recognition and accurate diagnosis in the clinical setting.
  • ➤ Dysgerminomas
  • ➤ exhibit lymphocytic infiltration
  • ➤ not nonlymphocytic infiltration
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1025-6
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1025-6

questions.text: All of the following are caused by lethal strains of HPV, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Laryngeal papillomatosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Cervical carcinoma: Persistent infection with these high-risk HPV types especially HPV 16, 18, 31 and 33 , can lead to the progression of cervical dysplasia to invasive carcinoma.
  • • Option
  • • A
  • • Cervical carcinoma:
  • • Persistent infection
  • • high-risk HPV types
  • • HPV 16, 18, 31 and 33
  • • progression of cervical dysplasia
  • • Option B . Oral carcinoma: HPV infection , especially with types 16 and 18 , has been linked to the development of oral and oropharyngeal cancers , particularly in the tonsillar and base of the tongue areas.
  • • Option
  • • B
  • • Oral carcinoma:
  • • HPV infection
  • • types 16 and 18
  • • linked to the development of oral
  • • oropharyngeal cancers
  • • Option D . Anorectal carcinoma: High-risk HPV types , including 16 and 18 , are implicated in the development of anal and anorectal carcinomas . These cancers are more prevalent in individuals with persistent HPV infection.
  • • Option
  • • D
  • • Anorectal carcinoma:
  • • High-risk HPV types
  • • 16 and 18
  • • development of anal
  • • anorectal carcinomas

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngeal papillomatosis is typically caused by the low-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) types 6 and 11 , which are not commonly associated with malignancy . In contrast, high-risk HPV types, particularly 16 and 18, are associated with an increased risk of developing cancers such as cervical carcinoma, oral carcinoma, and anorectal carcinoma.
  • ➤ Laryngeal papillomatosis
  • ➤ low-risk human papillomavirus
  • ➤ types 6 and 11
  • ➤ not commonly associated with malignancy

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with a history of persistent genital warts. Upon further investigation, it is found that the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) responsible for her condition produces a protein that interacts with the Retinoblastoma (Rb) tumor suppressor protein, leading to its degradation. Which of the following HPV proteins is involved in this process?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) E7

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. E6 protein of HPV interacts with cellular proteins , including p53 , leading to its degradation , which can disrupt cell cycle control and apoptosis regulation.
  • • Option A. E6
  • • protein
  • • HPV
  • • cellular proteins
  • • p53
  • • degradation
  • • Option C. LMP1: Latent Membrane Protein 1 is a protein produced by the Epstein-Barr virus . It plays a role in oncogenesis by activating signaling pathways involved in cell proliferation and survival.
  • • Option C. LMP1:
  • • Latent Membrane Protein 1
  • • protein
  • • Epstein-Barr virus
  • • Option D. Tax is a protein produced by the Human T-cell Leukemia Virus type 1 (HTLV-1), not HPV. Tax protein is known to interact with various cellular proteins and pathways, promoting cell proliferation and inhibiting apoptosis.
  • • Option D. Tax
  • • protein
  • • Human T-cell Leukemia Virus type 1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The HPV E7 protein has a role in promoting cellular proliferation and potential oncogenesis through interaction with the retinoblastoma (Rb) tumor suppressor protein , leading to its degradation.
  • ➤ HPV E7 protein
  • ➤ role in promoting cellular proliferation
  • ➤ potential oncogenesis
  • ➤ interaction
  • ➤ retinoblastoma
  • ➤ tumor suppressor protein
  • ➤ degradation.
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10th/e p324
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10th/e p324

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents for a routine Pap smear. The cytology report reveals koilocytes, nuclear enlargement, and perinuclear clearing in some of the cells. The fixative used in Pap smear is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ethanol

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Methanol is a fixative but not the primary choice for Pap smears because it can cause shrinkage and hardening of cells, which may interfere with cytological interpretation.
  • • Option A. Methanol
  • • fixative
  • • not the primary choice for Pap smears
  • • Option C. Formalin is used for histopathological specimens and is not suitable for Pap smears, as it can over-fix cells, leading to difficulties in cytological interpretation.
  • • Option C. Formalin
  • • histopathological specimens
  • • Option D. Air drying is not a fixative and can result in poor preservation of cellular morphology on Pap smear slides.
  • • Option D. Air drying
  • • not a fixative
  • • result in poor preservation of cellular morphology

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethanol is the primary fixative used in Pap smear preparations , effectively preserving the morphology of cervical cells for cytological evaluation and the identification of abnormalities such as koilocytes , which are indicative of HPV infection.
  • ➤ Ethanol
  • ➤ primary fixative
  • ➤ Pap smear preparations
  • ➤ preserving the morphology of cervical cells
  • ➤ cytological evaluation
  • ➤ identification of abnormalities
  • ➤ koilocytes

questions.text: The following are the instruments used in Pap smear:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cytobrush: It is a brush-like instrument used to collect cells from the endocervical canal .
  • • Option
  • • A.
  • • Cytobrush:
  • • brush-like instrument
  • • collect cells from the endocervical canal
  • • Option B. Ayer spatula : It is a wooden or plastic spatula used to sample cells from the outer cervix .
  • • Option
  • • B.
  • • Ayer spatula
  • • wooden or plastic spatula
  • • sample cells
  • • outer cervix
  • • Option C . Fixative and Retractor: After collecting the cells , they are transferred onto a glass slide , fixed , and then examined under a microscope . A retractor may be used to help visualize and access the cervix during the procedure.
  • • Option
  • • C
  • • Fixative and Retractor:
  • • collecting the cells
  • • transferred onto a glass slide
  • • fixed
  • • examined under a microscope
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • All of the mentioned instruments (cytobrush, Ayer spatula, fixative, and retractor) are used in the Pap smear procedure.

questions.text: Arrange the steps of Pap smear in the correct sequence: Retract vagina Take smear Make smear on the slide Fixate the slide
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The steps of Pap smear include retracting the vagina to visualize the cervix , taking a smear of cervical cells , making a smear on a slide , and fixating the slide with a suitable fixative like ethanol to preserve the sample for transportation and analysis .
  • • Pap smear
  • • retracting the vagina
  • • visualize the cervix
  • • smear of cervical cells
  • • smear on a slide
  • • fixating the slide
  • • suitable fixative
  • • ethanol
  • • preserve the sample
  • • transportation and analysis

questions.text: A female presented in the gynecology OPD with the presentation as given in the image. The examination revealed presence of high-risk HPV. Which of the following is the causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 18

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. HPV 6 is incorrect because it is associated with low-risk lesions such as genital warts rather than high-risk cervical pathologies.
  • • Option A. HPV 6
  • • associated with low-risk lesions
  • • genital warts
  • • Option B. HPV 11 is also incorrect for the same reason as HPV 6 ; it is linked to benign lesions and not high-risk cervical dysplasias or cancers.
  • • Option B. HPV 11
  • • same reason as HPV 6
  • • Option D. HPV 32 is not typically implicated in high-risk cervical disease .
  • • Option D. HPV 32
  • • implicated in high-risk cervical disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HPV 16 and 18 are involved in the pathogenesis of high-grade cervical dysplasias and cervical cancer .
  • ➤ HPV 16
  • ➤ 18 are involved in the pathogenesis
  • ➤ high-grade cervical dysplasias
  • ➤ cervical cancer
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1001
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1001

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman undergoes Pap smear which shows disorganised growth of the cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. Which phenomenon is occurring here?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dysplasia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Hypertrophy refers to an increase in the size of cells without an increase in the number of cells.
  • • Option A. Hypertrophy
  • • increase in the size of cells
  • • Option C. Metaplasia is a reversible change in which one adult cell type is replaced by another cell type.
  • • Option C. Metaplasia
  • • reversible change
  • • Option D. Hyperplasia is an increase in the number of cells in a tissue or organ.
  • • Option D. Hyperplasia
  • • increase in the number of cells
  • • tissue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dysplasia represents an early sign of potential malignant transformation in cervical epithelial cells and is characterized by disorganized cellular architecture and nuclear atypia .
  • ➤ Dysplasia
  • ➤ early sign
  • ➤ malignant transformation
  • ➤ cervical epithelial cells
  • ➤ disorganized cellular architecture
  • ➤ nuclear atypia
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10th/e p719-720
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10th/e p719-720

questions.text: Benign hyperplasia of prostate first develops in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Periurethral transition zone

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Incorrect, as the central zone is not the typical starting point for BPH .
  • • Option A.
  • • central zone
  • • not the typical starting point for BPH
  • • Option B. Incorrect, because the peripheral zone is primarily associated with prostate cancer rather than BPH.
  • • Option B.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Benign prostatic hyperplasia commonly begins in the periurethral transition zone of the prostate .

  • ➤ begins in the periurethral transition zone

questions.text: The commonest site for extragonadal germ cell tumour is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mediastinum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Pineal gland. While EGCTs can occur in the pineal gland, it is not the most common site for these tumors.
  • • Option A.
  • • Pineal gland.
  • • not the most common site
  • • Option C . Retroperitoneum . EGCTs can also arise in the retroperitoneum but less frequently than in the mediastinum.
  • • Option C
  • • Retroperitoneum
  • • arise in the retroperitoneum
  • • less frequently
  • • Option D. Sacrococcygeal region . Although EGCTs can be found in the sacrococcygeal region , it is a less common site compared to the mediastinum.
  • • Option D.
  • • Sacrococcygeal region
  • • EGCTs
  • • found in the sacrococcygeal region

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The mediastinum , especially the anterior mediastinum , is the most common site for extragonadal germ cell tumors .

  • ➤ anterior mediastinum

questions.text: Which one of the following is not used as a tumor marker in testicular tumors?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) CEA

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. AFP (Alpha-fetoprotein) is a tumor marker used in the diagnosis and management of non-seminomatous germ cell tumors of the testis .
  • • Option A.
  • • AFP
  • • tumor marker
  • • diagnosis and management
  • • non-seminomatous germ cell tumors
  • • testis
  • • Option B. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase) is a less specific marker but can be elevated in testicular cancers and is used to gauge prognosis and response to treatment.
  • • Option B.
  • • LDH
  • • less specific marker
  • • elevated in testicular cancers
  • • Option C. HCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin) is another marker important for certain types of testicular cancers , such as choriocarcinomas , and can also be elevated in other non-seminomatous germ cell tumors .
  • • Option C.
  • • HCG
  • • marker
  • • types of testicular cancers
  • • choriocarcinomas
  • • elevated
  • • non-seminomatous germ cell tumors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The tumor markers commonly used for testicular cancers include AFP, LDH , and HCG . CEA is not used as a marker for testicular tumors and is more relevant in other cancers like those of the gastrointestinal tract.
  • ➤ tumor markers
  • ➤ testicular cancers
  • ➤ AFP, LDH
  • ➤ HCG
  • ➤ CEA
  • ➤ not
  • ➤ marker for testicular tumors

  • ➤ Ref

questions.text: All of the following genes are associated with seminoma except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) CDK-4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. PLAP (Placental Alkaline Phosphatase) is a tumor marker expressed in seminomas and can be used in the diagnosis and follow-up of patients with this type of tumor.
  • • Option A.
  • • PLAP
  • • tumor marker expressed in seminomas
  • • used in the diagnosis
  • • follow-up of patients
  • • Option B. C-KIT is a proto-oncogene that encodes for a tyrosine kinase receptor ; mutations in C-KIT are found in a subset of seminomas, making it relevant to their pathogenesis.
  • • Option B. C-KIT
  • • proto-oncogene
  • • encodes for a tyrosine kinase receptor
  • • Option C. OCT-4 (Octamer-binding transcription factor 4) is a transcription factor involved in maintaining the pluripotency of embryonic stem cells . It is highly expressed in seminomas and is considered a reliable diagnostic marker.
  • • Option C. OCT-4
  • • transcription factor
  • • maintaining the pluripotency
  • • embryonic stem cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When assessing seminomas , key genes to consider include PLAP, C-KIT, and OCT-4 , which are commonly expressed in these tumors . CDK-4 is not specifically linked to seminomas and is more generally involved in the cell cycle regulation of many cell types .
  • ➤ assessing seminomas
  • ➤ PLAP, C-KIT,
  • ➤ OCT-4
  • ➤ expressed in these tumors
  • ➤ CDK-4
  • ➤ not
  • ➤ linked to seminomas
  • ➤ involved in the cell cycle regulation
  • ➤ many cell types
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10th/ 978
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10th/ 978

questions.text: The cytogenicity of solid tumors is not easily assessed especially in carcinoma cervix because:

options.label: B
options.text: Due to contamination with infectious agents

questions.correct_answer: B. Due to contamination with infectious agents
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Due to contamination with infectious agents

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option C. While a high mitotic rate is a characteristic of rapidly dividing cancer cells , it doesn't necessarily hinder cytogenetic analysis . In fact, a high mitotic rate is often beneficial for cytogenetic studies as it provides more cells in the dividing phase for analysis.
  • • Option C.
  • • high mitotic rate
  • • characteristic of rapidly dividing cancer cells
  • • doesn't
  • • hinder cytogenetic analysis
  • • high mitotic rate
  • • beneficial for cytogenetic studies
  • • Option D. Deficient tissue sample : A deficient tissue sample may indeed hinder cytogenetic analysis . If the sample is insufficient or of low quality , it may not yield enough viable cells for proper analysis.
  • • Option D.
  • • Deficient tissue sample
  • • deficient tissue sample
  • • hinder cytogenetic analysis
  • • sample is insufficient
  • • low quality
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Deficient tissue sampling like sampling from non-representative areas or the necrotic areas will impair the results in most of the solid tumors but the commonest problem with cancer of the cervix is the high contamination rate . So, option ‘B’ is better than option ‘D’.
  • • Deficient tissue sampling
  • • sampling from non-representative areas
  • • necrotic areas
  • • impair the results
  • • solid tumors
  • • commonest problem with cancer of the cervix
  • • high contamination rate

questions.text: With regard to the malignant behavior of leiomyosarcoma, the most important criterion is:

options.label: A
options.text: Blood vessel penetration by tumor cells

options.label: D
options.text: The number of mitoses per high power field

questions.correct_answer: D. The number of mitoses per high power field
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The number of mitoses per high power field

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Blood vessel penetration by tumor cells is a feature observed in malignant tumors . However, while significant, it is not the most critical factor in diagnosing leiomyosarcoma.
  • • Option A. Blood vessel penetration by tumor cells
  • • feature observed in malignant tumors
  • • Option B. The presence of tumor cells in lymphatic channels is another indication of potential malignancy and can signify the spread of cancer, but it's not the primary criterion for diagnosis.
  • • Option B. The presence of tumor cells in lymphatic channels
  • • indication of potential malignancy
  • • Option C. Lymphocyte infiltration is often a sign of an immune response to the tumor rather than a direct indication of malignancy.
  • • Option C. Lymphocyte infiltration
  • • sign of an immune response to the tumor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A high mitotic index is indicative of aggressive tumor behavior and malignancy , aiding in the differentiation between benign and malignant smooth muscle tumors such as leiomyomas and leiomyosarcomas , respectively.
  • ➤ high mitotic index
  • ➤ aggressive tumor behavior
  • ➤ malignancy
  • ➤ differentiation between benign
  • ➤ malignant smooth muscle tumors
  • ➤ leiomyomas
  • ➤ leiomyosarcomas
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1021
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1021

questions.text: Sections from a solid-cystic unilateral ovarian tumor in a 30-year-old female show a tumor composed of diffuse sheets of small cells with doubtful nuclear grooving and scanty cytoplasm. No Call-Exner bodies are seen. The ideal immunohistochemistry panel would include:

options.label: A
options.text: Vimentin, epithelial membrane antigen, inhibin, CD99

options.label: B
options.text: Desmin, S-100 protein, smooth muscle antigen, cytokeratin

questions.correct_answer: A. Vimentin, epithelial membrane antigen, inhibin, CD99
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vimentin, epithelial membrane antigen, inhibin, CD99

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Encompasses markers like Desmin and Smooth Muscle Antigen (SMA) for smooth muscle tumors , S-100 for neural tumors , and Cytokeratin for epithelial tumors . This panel isn’t as specific for granulosa cell tumors as Option A.
  • • Option B:
  • • Encompasses markers
  • • Desmin and Smooth Muscle Antigen
  • • smooth muscle tumors
  • • S-100
  • • neural tumors
  • • Cytokeratin for epithelial tumors
  • • Option C: Has markers like Chromogranin and CD45 , which are used for neuroendocrine and hematolymphoid tumors , respectively.
  • • Option C:
  • • markers like Chromogranin
  • • CD45
  • • used for neuroendocrine
  • • hematolymphoid tumors
  • • Option D: Includes CD3 and CD45 , markers for T-lymphocytes and leukocytes respectively, along with Chromogranin and Synaptophysin , which are neuroendocrine markers. This panel is not suitable for a granulosa cell tumor.
  • • Option D:
  • • CD3 and CD45
  • • markers for T-lymphocytes
  • • leukocytes
  • • Chromogranin
  • • Synaptophysin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In diagnosing granulosa cell tumors , an IHC panel including Vimentin, EMA , Inhibin , and CD99 can be valuable . Vimentin and Inhibin are particularly important in this setting, with Inhibin being a specific marker for sex cord-stromal tumors like granulosa cell tumors . The absence of Call-Exner bodies does not exclude the diagnosis of granulosa cell tumors , as these are not present in all cases. This panel can help confirm the diagnosis and differentiate it from other neoplasms.
  • ➤ diagnosing granulosa cell tumors
  • ➤ IHC panel including Vimentin, EMA
  • ➤ Inhibin
  • ➤ CD99
  • ➤ valuable
  • ➤ Vimentin
  • ➤ Inhibin
  • ➤ Inhibin being a specific marker for sex cord-stromal tumors
  • ➤ granulosa cell tumors
  • ➤ absence of Call-Exner bodies
  • ➤ not exclude the diagnosis of granulosa cell tumors

questions.text: A patient with chronic pelvic pain undergoes a hysterectomy. The resected uterus is filled with nodules composed of benign smooth muscle cells. Which of the following terms best describes these nodules?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Leiomyoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Angiosarcoma: This term refers to a malignant tumor derived from blood vessels , not smooth muscle.
  • • Option A. Angiosarcoma:
  • • refers to a malignant tumor
  • • blood vessels
  • • Option C. Leiomyosarcoma: This term refers to a malignant smooth muscle tumor , and the description in the question indicates benign nodules.
  • • Option C. Leiomyosarcoma:
  • • malignant smooth muscle tumor
  • • Option D. Rhabdomyoma: This term refers to a benign tumor derived from striated muscle , not smooth muscle.
  • • Option D. Rhabdomyoma:
  • • benign tumor derived from striated muscle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Leiomyomas are benign neoplasms originating from the myometrium and are commonly referred to as uterine fibroids . They are the most prevalent benign gynecological tumors in women of reproductive age and are often associated with symptoms like chronic pelvic pain , abnormal uterine bleeding , and reproductive dysfunction .
  • ➤ Leiomyomas
  • ➤ benign neoplasms
  • ➤ myometrium
  • ➤ commonly referred to as uterine fibroids
  • ➤ most prevalent benign gynecological tumors
  • ➤ women of reproductive age
  • ➤ chronic pelvic pain
  • ➤ abnormal uterine bleeding
  • ➤ reproductive dysfunction
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1021
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1021

questions.text: Endodermal sinus tumor is characterized by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Schiller-Duval body

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Call Exner body: Seen in granulosa cell tumors of the ovary .
  • • Option A. Call Exner body:
  • • granulosa cell tumors
  • • ovary
  • • Option B. Psammoma body: Seen in various tumors , including papillary thyroid carcinoma and serous ovarian tumors .
  • • Option B. Psammoma body:
  • • various tumors
  • • papillary thyroid carcinoma
  • • serous ovarian tumors
  • • Option D. Homer Wright body: Seen in neuroblastoma and medulloblastoma.
  • • Option D. Homer Wright body:
  • • neuroblastoma
  • • medulloblastoma.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of Schiller-Duval bodies is a distinctive histological feature of endodermal sinus tumors (yolk sac tumors), which are aggressive germ cell neoplasms often found in the gonads . Recognition of these bodies, which resemble a glomerulus with a central blood vessel surrounded by germ cells , aids in differentiating endodermal sinus tumors from other germ cell tumors . They are a pathognomonic finding, supporting the diagnosis when identified microscopically.
  • ➤ presence of Schiller-Duval bodies
  • ➤ histological feature
  • ➤ endodermal sinus tumors
  • ➤ aggressive germ cell neoplasms
  • ➤ gonads
  • ➤ resemble a glomerulus
  • ➤ central blood vessel
  • ➤ germ cells
  • ➤ differentiating endodermal sinus tumors
  • ➤ other germ cell tumors
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th / 974
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th / 974

questions.text: An adenofibroma of the ovary in which the epithelial component consists of the nests of transitional cells is called:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Brenner tumour

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Thecoma: An ovarian sex cord-stromal tumor .
  • • Option A. Thecoma:
  • • ovarian sex cord-stromal tumor
  • • Option C. Serous cystadenoma: An ovarian epithelial tumor characterized by the presence of serous cysts .
  • • Option C. Serous cystadenoma:
  • • ovarian epithelial tumor
  • • presence of serous cysts
  • • Option D. Granulosa cell tumor: Another type of ovarian sex cord-stromal tumor .
  • • Option D. Granulosa cell tumor:
  • • ovarian sex cord-stromal tumor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ The Brenner tumor is an uncommon ovarian neoplasm characterized by solid and cystic components with transitional epithelium resembling bladder urothelium . The histopathological features of Brenner tumours often present as nests of transitional cells.
  • ➤ Brenner tumor
  • ➤ uncommon ovarian neoplasm
  • ➤ solid and cystic components
  • ➤ transitional epithelium
  • ➤ bladder urothelium
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1025
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1025

questions.text: A lady with abdominal mass was investigated. On surgery, she was found to have bilateral ovarian masses with smooth surface. On microscopy they revealed mucin secreting cells with signet ring shape. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Krukenberg tumor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Dysgerminoma: Dysgerminomas are germ cell tumors typically found in the ovaries . Histologically, they are characterized by uniform, undifferentiated cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei. They do not have the mucin-secreting signet ring cells that are characteristic of Krukenberg tumors.
  • • Option A. Dysgerminoma:
  • • germ cell tumors
  • • found in the ovaries
  • • Option C. Mucinous Adenocarcinoma of the Ovaries: Primary mucinous adenocarcinomas of the ovaries originate within the ovary itself . They also contain mucin-secreting cells, but unlike Krukenberg tumors, they are not metastatic and typically present as multilocular cystic masses with a sticky gelatinous fluid.
  • • Option C. Mucinous Adenocarcinoma of the Ovaries:
  • • Primary mucinous adenocarcinomas
  • • ovaries originate within the ovary itself
  • • Option D. Dermoid Cyst: Also known as mature cystic teratomas , dermoid cysts are benign tumors that contain well-differentiated derivations from at least two of the three germ layers : ectoderm , mesoderm , and endoderm . They may contain various tissues such as hair, teeth, and sebaceous material, and are not associated with signet ring cells or mucin production.
  • • Option D. Dermoid Cyst:
  • • mature cystic teratomas
  • • dermoid cysts
  • • benign tumors
  • • well-differentiated derivations
  • • two of the three germ layers
  • • ectoderm
  • • mesoderm
  • • endoderm
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The presence of bilateral ovarian masses with mucin-secreting signet ring cells is pathognomonic for a Krukenberg tumor , which indicates that the primary tumor is most likely in the gastrointestinal tract , especially the stomach .
  • • presence of bilateral ovarian masses
  • • mucin-secreting signet ring cells
  • • pathognomonic for a Krukenberg tumor
  • • primary tumor
  • • gastrointestinal tract
  • • stomach
  • • Ref : Robbins 10 th 1030
  • • Ref
  • • : Robbins 10 th 1030

questions.text: Most common subtype of endometrial carcinoma on histopathology is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Adenocarcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Clear Cell: Clear cell carcinoma of the endometrium is a rare subtype and is typically associated with a more aggressive behavior and worse prognosis than endometrioid adenocarcinoma.
  • • Option A. Clear Cell:
  • • endometrium
  • • rare subtype
  • • more aggressive behavior
  • • worse prognosis
  • • Option C. Squamous Cell Carcinoma : Squamous cell carcinoma of the endometrium is exceedingly rare because the endometrium normally does not contain squamous cells ; they may appear secondary to metaplastic processes.
  • • Option C. Squamous Cell Carcinoma
  • • endometrium
  • • exceedingly rare
  • • endometrium normally
  • • not contain squamous cells
  • • Option D. Transitional Cell Carcinoma: Transitional cell carcinoma is another rare subtype of endometrial cancer that resembles urothelial carcinoma of the bladder . This type of carcinoma is not commonly found in the endometrium.
  • • Option D. Transitional Cell Carcinoma:
  • • another rare subtype
  • • endometrial cancer
  • • resembles urothelial carcinoma of the bladder
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Adenocarcinoma , especially the endometrioid subtype , is the most common form of endometrial cancer .
  • • Adenocarcinoma
  • • endometrioid subtype
  • • common
  • • endometrial cancer
  • • Ref : Robbins 10 th / 1010
  • • Ref
  • • : Robbins 10 th / 1010

questions.text: All are true about condylomata acuminata except which of the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Progresses to malignancy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Caused by HPV This statement is true . Condylomata acuminata, also known as genital warts, are caused by certain types of the human papillomavirus (HPV), particularly HPV types 6 and 11.
  • • Option A. Caused by HPV
  • • true
  • • Option B. Sexually transmitted This is true as well. HPV, which causes condylomata acuminata, is transmitted through sexual contact.
  • • Option B. Sexually transmitted
  • • true
  • • Option D. Occurs in genitalia This statement is true . Condylomata acuminata typically appear in the moist mucocutaneous regions of the genitalia and are characterized by their cauliflower-like appearance.
  • • Option D. Occurs in genitalia
  • • true

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Condylomata acuminata are benign lesions caused by HPV and are sexually transmitted . They typically appear in the genitalia and, while they may persist or recur, they rarely progress to malignancy .
  • ➤ Condylomata acuminata
  • ➤ benign lesions
  • ➤ HPV
  • ➤ sexually transmitted
  • ➤ appear in the genitalia
  • ➤ rarely progress to malignancy
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th / 970
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th / 970

questions.text: Risk factor for endometrial carcinoma is all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Smoking

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Obesity: Obese women have an increased risk of endometrial carcinoma , likely due to the excess production of estrogen in adipose tissue .
  • • Option A. Obesity:
  • • increased risk of endometrial carcinoma
  • • excess production
  • • estrogen
  • • adipose tissue
  • • Option C. Infertility: Infertile women, especially those with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), are at an increased risk . This may be related to anovulation and unopposed estrogen stimulation .
  • • Option C. Infertility:
  • • polycystic ovary syndrome
  • • increased risk
  • • anovulation
  • • unopposed estrogen stimulation
  • • Option D. Tamoxifen: Tamoxifen, a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used in the treatment of breast cancer , has estrogenic effects on the endometrium and is associated with an increased risk of endometrial carcinoma .
  • • Option D. Tamoxifen:
  • • selective estrogen receptor modulator
  • • treatment of breast cancer
  • • estrogenic effects
  • • endometrium
  • • increased risk of endometrial carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Obesity , infertility , and the use of tamoxifen are known risk factors for developing endometrial carcinoma . In contrast, smoking has been associated with a decreased risk of endometrial carcinoma , likely due to its anti-estrogenic effects , which counteract the estrogen-driven proliferation of the endometrial lining .
  • ➤ Obesity
  • ➤ infertility
  • ➤ use of tamoxifen
  • ➤ risk factors
  • ➤ endometrial carcinoma
  • ➤ smoking
  • ➤ associated with a decreased risk of endometrial carcinoma
  • ➤ anti-estrogenic effects
  • ➤ counteract
  • ➤ estrogen-driven proliferation
  • ➤ endometrial lining
  • ➤ Ref : Robbins 10 th 1012
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : Robbins 10 th 1012

questions.text: Most common primary ovarian tumor amongst the following is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Serous cystadenoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Fibroma: Fibromas are ovarian tumors composed of fibrous tissue .
  • • Option A. Fibroma:
  • • ovarian tumors
  • • fibrous tissue
  • • Option B. Ovarian teratomas , also known as dermoid cysts , are the neoplasms that can contain elements derived from all three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm)
  • • Option B. Ovarian teratomas
  • • dermoid cysts
  • • neoplasms
  • • Option C. Mucinous cystadenoma: Mucinous cystadenomas are ovarian tumors that contain mucin-secreting epithelial cells ..
  • • Option C. Mucinous cystadenoma:
  • • ovarian tumors
  • • mucin-secreting epithelial cells
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Serous cystadenomas are the most common ovarian neoplasms .
  • • Serous cystadenomas
  • • most common ovarian neoplasms
  • • Ref : Robbins 10 th 1024
  • • Ref
  • • : Robbins 10 th 1024

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman experienced dull pain in lower abdomen for past 6 months and minimal vaginal bleeding on 3 occasions. Her last menstrual period was 12 years ago. Pelvic examination shows a right adnexal mass and the uterus appears normal in size. An abdominal ultrasound shows 8 cm solid mass. A total abdominal hysterectomy was done and mass was diagnosed as granulosa tumour. Which of the following additional lesion is most likely to be found in excised specimen?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. A partial hydatidiform mole is a gestational trophoblastic disease characterized by abnormal fetal development and hydropic changes in the placenta . It's more associated with abnormalities in fertilization and placental development during pregnancy .
  • • Option A.
  • • A partial hydatidiform mole
  • • gestational trophoblastic disease
  • • abnormal fetal development
  • • hydropic changes
  • • placenta
  • • abnormalities in fertilization
  • • placental development
  • • pregnancy
  • • Option C. While metastases can occur in various cancers , granulosa cell tumors of the ovary typically spread within the pelvic and abdominal cavities . Distant metastases, especially to the uterine serosa, are less common.
  • • Option C.
  • • While metastases can occur in various cancers
  • • granulosa cell tumors
  • • ovary
  • • spread within the pelvic
  • • abdominal cavities
  • • Option D. Condyloma acuminata , caused by human papillomavirus (HPV), is a sexually transmitted infection that manifests as genital warts . It is unrelated to granulosa cell tumors of the ovary.
  • • Option D.
  • • Condyloma acuminata
  • • human papillomavirus
  • • sexually transmitted infection
  • • genital warts

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ It is important to recognize the endocrine effects of granulosa cell tumors , which are a type of sex cord-stromal tumor of the ovary . These tumors are known to secrete estrogen , which can lead to proliferative changes in the endometrium , such as endometrial hyperplasia . In postmenopausal women , unopposed estrogen can significantly increase the risk of developing endometrial hyperplasia , which can progress to endometrial carcinoma .
  • ➤ recognize the endocrine effects of granulosa cell tumors
  • ➤ type of sex cord-stromal tumor
  • ➤ ovary
  • ➤ tumors
  • ➤ secrete estrogen
  • ➤ proliferative changes
  • ➤ endometrium
  • ➤ endometrial hyperplasia
  • ➤ postmenopausal women
  • ➤ unopposed estrogen
  • ➤ increase the risk of developing endometrial hyperplasia
  • ➤ endometrial carcinoma
